text: no kitchen should be without one of
these a cast-iron skillet but instead of
having a smooth black surface like this
does yours look more like this rusty and
discolored well I'm going to show you I
properly care for your cast-iron skillet
and I've actually received a lot of
comments and everybody wants to know how
to do this so a soiled cast-iron skillet
I have one here this is from frying an
egg but you can use cast-iron skillets
for so many things whether it's frying
it's searing but instead of washing this
pan what you should do is use a little
bit of coarse salt this is kosher salt
and just sprinkle it into the bottom of
the pan not using water here I'm not
using soap and a couple of paper towels
and rub the salt into the stuck-on food
in the pan and you can see it acts
almost as a scrub brush because it
really helps as an abrasive and it gets
any of that stuck on food off if you
need a little bit more salt you can add
as you go so I'm just going to dump this
out and then you're going to heat this
over low heat and what this does if
there's any moisture left on the surface
it will evaporate and you won't get any
rusting so gently heat it until it's dry
as a bone and then you can wipe it out
again and you can store it so now if you
have found a rusty cast-iron skillet
maybe have it a tag sale maybe you've
inherited it and you need to clean it
I'm going to show you how to do that
right now and that's easy because all
you're going to do here is you're going
to put a little bit of soap not too much
don't use too much and some water and
you're just going to scrub out the rut
use a SIF bristle brush and you have to
use a little bit of elbow grease here
dump it out rinse it out see how much of
the rust is left
and just repeat this process until
there's no rust left in the bottom of
the pan so this looks good the water is
running clear just going to rinse out
any soap and now it's the same process
you have to heat this over a low flame
so that all of the water and moisture
comes out of the pan so that it doesn't
rust again so now the pan is nice and
dry and I'm going to season the pan now
and what that means is it's adding a
little bit of oil and what this does is
it helps to start forming a nonstick
surface so about a tablespoon of oil and
I'm using a neutral oil here a grapeseed
or safflower you wouldn't want to use
olive oil here just rub it into the pan
and then this has to stay over a low
heat the lowest possible setting on your
stovetop or into a 300 degree oven for
about an hour and what that does is the
oil kind of bakes into all of the
crevices of the pan and it creates a
nonstick surface which is perfect for
cooking cool it to room temperature and
then you're ready to store it and after
time and after use you really do create
a wonderful nonstick surface that's
perfect for pan searing for frying for
sauteing really anything and now we know
how to properly care for your cast iron
skillet
